ygData.subject: Re: Input encoding with HyperNEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: I m totally new to all of this, but I think you might consider two banks of inputs that each encode a binary number.  The first bank is the binary encoding

I'm totally new to all of this, but I think you might consider two "banks" =
of inputs that each encode a binary number.  The first bank is the binary e=
ncoding (01001 for node #9 for instance) for one node and the second bank i=
s the same for the second node.

I think it all depends on what kinds of pa=
tterns you think might exist with respect to the node IDs I guess.  I mean,=
 if you think that all nodes whose IDs are divisible by 3 evenly are connec=
ted to those whose IDs are divisible by 3 with a modulus of 1, then doing a=
 different encoding scheme taking that into effect might work better.

Agai=
n, I'm a NN novice and just starting to learn NEAT myself!


-- Chris


---=
 In neat@yahoogroups.com, "p_mridul" <p_mridul@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> 
> I a=
m working on a bioinformatics problem, but it's easier to talk about it in =
graph theory terms....
> 
> I have a graph with a large number of nodes (~9=
000), and about 3000 edges between the nodes... I am planning to feed this =
as training data, and then see if the resulting NN will predict the probabi=
lity of an edge given any 2 nodes.
> 
> I have questions of how to encode t=
he inputs... do I create an input array of 9000 inputs and pass in the coup=
le of 1's corresponding to the nodes, or do I choose 2 inputs & pass in the=
 node numbers?
> 
> Thanks,
> Mridul.
>
